abandon: withdrawing support or help despite allegiance or responsibility
abdiquer: end resistance, as under pressure or force
abeille: any of numerous hairy-bodied insects including social and solitary species
aborder: twist suddenly so as to sprain
aboutir: come to have or undergo a change of (physical features and attributes)
abreuver: supply with water, as with channels or ditches or streams
abriter: return home accurately from a long distance
abroger: remove completely from recognition or memory
abrupt: surprisingly and unceremoniously brusque in manner
absurde: inconsistent with reason or logic or common sense; - Walter Lippman
abusif: characterized by physical or psychological maltreatment
acajou: any of various tropical timber trees of the family Meliaceae especially the genus Swietinia valued for their hard yellowish- to reddish-brown wood that is readily worked and takes a high polish
accolade: squeeze (someone) tightly in your arms, usually with fondness
acerbe: marked by strong resentment or cynicism
achat: the acquisition of something for payment
acheter: the acquisition of something for payment
acier: cover, plate, or edge with steel
acompte: a partial payment made at the time of purchase; the balance to be paid later
acronyme: a word formed from the initial letters of the several words in the name
actuel: presently existing in fact and not merely potential or possible
adepte: someone who travels behind or pursues another
adjectif: relating to court practice and procedure as opposed to the principles of law
adjuger: distribute according to a plan or set apart for a special purpose
adresse: adjust and aim (a golf ball) at in preparation of hitting
adroit: quick or skillful or adept in action or thought
adverbe: the word class that qualifies verbs or clauses
affecter: act physically on; have an effect upon
agiter: causing to move repeatedly from side to side
agrume: any of numerous fruits of the genus Citrus having thick rind and juicy pulp; grown in warm regions
aiguille: goad or provoke,as by constant criticism
aisance: a covered cistern; waste water and sewage flow into it
ajouter: make an addition (to); join or combine or unite with others; increase the quality, quantity, size or scope of
ajuster: adapt or conform oneself to new or different conditions
alchimie: a pseudoscientific forerunner of chemistry in medieval times
alerte: a device that signals the occurrence of some undesirable event
algue: primitive chlorophyll-containing mainly aquatic eukaryotic organisms lacking true stems and roots and leaves
aliment: any substance that can be metabolized by an animal to give energy and build tissue
allouer: give or assign a resource to a particular person or cause
alpaga: domesticated llama with long silky fleece; believed to be a domesticated variety of the guanaco
altesse: the quality of being high or lofty
ambigu: having more than one possible meaning
ambre: of a medium to dark brownish yellow color
amertume: the property of having a harsh unpleasant taste
amiral: any of several brightly colored butterflies
amorcer: begin to speak or say;  he began
amour: sexual activities (often including sexual intercourse) between two people
amovible: designed to be unfastened or disconnected without damage
amphibie: operating or living on land and in water
ampleur: a magnifier of images of distant objects
analyse: an investigation of the component parts of a whole and their relations in making up the whole
anaphore: repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning of successive clauses
anarchie: a state of lawlessness and disorder (usually resulting from a failure of government)
ancien: just preceding something else in time or order
angoisse: a vague unpleasant emotion that is experienced in anticipation of some (usually ill-defined) misfortune
anguleux: having angles or an angular shape
animal: a living organism characterized by voluntary movement
anomalie: (astronomy) position of a planet as defined by its angular distance from its perihelion (as observed from the sun)
anonyme: having no known name or identity or known source
antenne: one of a pair of mobile appendages on the head of e.g. insects and crustaceans; typically sensitive to touch and taste
antidote: a remedy that stops or controls the effects of a poison
apaiser: cause to be calm or quiet as by administering a sedative to
apologie: the act of vindicating or defending against criticism or censure etc.
appareil: equipment designed to serve a specific function
appeler: the option to buy a given stock (or stock index or commodity future) at a given price before a given date
appuyer: strengthen by providing with a back or backing

aqueduc: a conduit that resembles a bridge but carries water over a valley
ardeur: the trait of being intensely emotional
armature: coil in which voltage is induced by motion through a magnetic field
armement: the act of equiping with weapons in preparation for war
armoire: a large wardrobe or cabinet; originally used for storing weapons
armure: tough more-or-less rigid protective covering of an animal or plant
arpenter: a step in walking or running
arracher: destroy completely, as if down to the roots
arroser: supply with water, as with channels or ditches or streams
arsenic: a very poisonous metallic element that has three allotropic forms; arsenic and arsenic compounds are used as herbicides and insecticides and various alloys; found in arsenopyrite and orpiment and realgar
article: one of a class of artifacts
aspect: the act of appearing in public view
aspirer: have an ambitious plan or a lofty goal
assaut: (military) an offensive against an enemy (using weapons)
asservir: make a slave of; bring into servitude
assiette: the position on a baseball team of the player who is stationed behind home plate and who catches the balls that the pitcher throws
associer: make a logical or causal connection
asticot: the larva of the housefly and blowfly commonly found in decaying organic matter
astre: natural objects visible in the sky
atelier: a brief intensive course for a small group; emphasizes problem solving
atome: (nontechnical usage) a tiny piece of anything
atrium: the central area in a building; open to the sky
attentif: (often followed by `to') giving care or attention
attraper: the act of catching an object with the hands
aubaine: a sudden happening that brings good fortune (as a sudden opportunity to make money)
auberge: a house separate from the main house; for housing guests
audible: heard or perceptible by the ear
automne: pass suddenly and passively into a state of body or mind
autruche: fast-running African flightless bird with two-toed feet; largest living bird
avaler: believe or accept without questioning or challenge
avarice: reprehensible acquisitiveness; insatiable desire for wealth (personified as one of the deadly sins)
avenir: coming at a subsequent time or stage
aveugle: make dim by comparison or conceal
avide: given to excess in consumption of especially food or drink
avoine: seed of the annual grass Avena sativa (spoken of primarily in the plural as `oats')
avril: the month following March and preceding May
axial: situated on or along or in the direction of an axis
axiome: (logic) a proposition that is not susceptible of proof or disproof; its truth is assumed to be self-evident
bafouer: injure by trampling or as if by trampling
bagage: cases used to carry belongings when traveling
baguette: one of a pair of slender sticks used as oriental tableware to eat food with
baignade: an ancient Hebrew liquid measure equal to about 10 gallons
balcon: a platform projecting from the wall of a building and surrounded by a balustrade or railing or parapet
bambin: very small European freshwater fish common in gravelly streams

banquier: the person in charge of the bank in a gambling game
barbier: perform the services of a barber: cut the hair and/or beard of
baril: any of various units of capacity
baron: a very wealthy or powerful businessman
barque: a sailing ship with 3 (or more) masts
barrage: female parent of an animal especially domestic livestock
bastion: a stronghold into which people could go for shelter during a battle
bataille: an energetic attempt to achieve something
batterie: an assault in which the assailant makes physical contact
baudrier: a wide (ornamented) belt worn over the right shoulder to support a sword or bugle by the left hip
belette: type genus of the family Mustelidae: minks and weasels
berceau: a game played with string looped over the fingers
berger: any of various usually long-haired breeds of dog reared to herd and guard sheep
berline: a car that is closed and that has front and rear seats and two or four doors

besogne: a legal document signed and sealed and delivered to effect a transfer of property and to show the legal right to possess it
bidule: a device or control that is very useful for a particular job
bijou: adorn or decorate with precious stones
bilan: (nautical) a line (rope or chain) that regulates the angle at which a sail is set in relation to the wind
billard: any of several games played on rectangular cloth-covered table (with cushioned edges) in which long tapering cue sticks are used to propel ivory (or composition) balls
binaire: consisting of two (units or components or elements or terms)
biologie: the science that studies living organisms
biopsie: examination of tissues or liquids from the living body to determine the existence or cause of a disease
biotype: organisms sharing a specified genotype or the genotype (or peculiarities) so shared
biscuit: a short line of text that a web site puts on your computer's hard drive when you access the web site
bistouri: a thin straight surgical knife used in dissection and surgery
bizarre: conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual
blanchir: convert illegally obtained funds into legal ones
blond: being or having light colored skin and hair and usually blue or grey eyes
bloquer: hold back, as of a danger or an enemy; check the expansion or influence of
bobine: wind onto a spool or a reel
boire: be fascinated or spell-bound by; pay close attention to

bondir: move forward by leaps and bounds
bonheur: something or someone that provides a source of happiness
bordure: the outside limit of an object or area or surface; a place farthest away from the center of something

botte: footwear that covers the whole foot and lower leg

boueux: dirty and messy; covered with mud or muck
bougie: examine eggs for freshness by holding them against a light
bouquin: United States author whose novels drew on her experiences as a missionary in China (1892-1973)

boussole: travel around, either by plane or ship
boutique: a course of instruction in a trade (as carpentry or electricity)
boxeur: a member of a nationalistic Chinese secret society that led an unsuccessful rebellion in 1900 against foreign interests in China

brioche: a light roll rich with eggs and butter and somewhat sweet
brique: a solid piece of something (usually having flat rectangular sides)

bronzer: expose one's body to the sun
broyeur: a device that shreds documents (usually in order to prevent the wrong people from reading them)
brusque: marked by rude or peremptory shortness
bruyant: characterized by or producing sound of great volume or intensity

bureau: a religious rite or service prescribed by ecclesiastical authorities
burin: a chisel of tempered steel with a sharp point; used for engraving
butoir: a person who is the aim of an attack (especially a victim of ridicule or exploitation) by some hostile person or influence

cachette: a hiding place; usually a remote place used by outlaws
cadeau: recognize with a gesture prescribed by a military regulation; assume a prescribed position

calculer: the act of counting; reciting numbers in ascending order
calibre: a degree or grade of excellence or worth
calmer: cause to be calm or quiet as by administering a sedative to
calomnie: an abusive attack on a person's character or good name

camarade: an associate who provides cooperation or assistance

cantine: a restaurant where you serve yourself and pay a cashier
canular: something intended to deceive; deliberate trickery intended to gain an advantage
caprice: an odd or fanciful or capricious idea
capsule: put in a short or concise form; reduce in volume
carbone: a copy made with carbon paper
caresser: a gentle affectionate stroking (or something resembling it)
caribou: Arctic deer with large antlers in both sexes; called `reindeer' in Eurasia and `caribou' in North America
carnage: the savage and excessive killing of many people
carreau: stratified stone that splits into pieces suitable as paving stones
cascade: a steep descent of the water of a river
casque: (15-16th century) any armor for the head; usually ornate without a visor
caution: the legal system that allows an accused person to be temporarily released from custody (usually on condition that a sum of money guarantees their appearance at trial)
caviar: salted roe of sturgeon or other large fish; usually served as an hors d'oeuvre
cellule: (biology) the basic structural and functional unit of all organisms; they may exist as independent units of life (as in monads) or may form colonies or tissues as in higher plants and animals
cendrier: a bin that holds rubbish until it is collected
censurer: subject to political, religious, or moral censorship
central: in or near a center or constituting a center; the inner area
cerise: of a color at the end of the color spectrum (next to orange); resembling the color of blood or cherries or tomatoes or rubies
cerner: find the solution to (a problem or question) or understand the meaning of

chapitre: a heading that names a statute or legislative bill; may give a brief summary of the matters it deals with

chausson: low footwear that can be slipped on and off easily; usually worn indoors
chenille: a wormlike and often brightly colored and hairy or spiny larva of a butterfly or moth
cheval: provide with a horse or horses
chien: a member of the genus Canis (probably descended from the common wolf) that has been domesticated by man since prehistoric times; occurs in many breeds
chiffre: of or relating to or denoting numbers
chignon: a roll of hair worn at the nape of the neck
chlorure: any salt of hydrochloric acid (containing the chloride ion)

chouette: nocturnal bird of prey with hawk-like beak and claws and large head with front-facing eyes

cirque: a performance given by a traveling company of acrobats, clowns, and trained animals
citerne: an artificial reservoir for storing liquids; especially an underground tank for storing rainwater

civil: of or in a condition of social order
claquer: break suddenly and abruptly, as under tension
classe: education imparted in a series of lessons or meetings
clavier: holder consisting of an arrangement of hooks on which keys or locks can be hung
client: (computer science) any computer that is hooked up to a computer network
climat: the weather in some location averaged over some long period of time
clonage: a general term for the research activity that creates a copy of some biological entity (a gene or organism or cell)
cloporte: any of various small terrestrial isopods having a flat elliptical segmented body; found in damp habitats
cobalt: a hard ferromagnetic silver-white bivalent or trivalent metallic element; a trace element in plant and animal nutrition
cobra: venomous Asiatic and African elapid snakes that can expand the skin of the neck into a hood
cocotier: large hard-shelled oval nut with a fibrous husk containing thick white meat surrounding a central cavity filled (when fresh) with fluid or milk
coder: organize into a code or system, such as a body of law
codifier: organize into a code or system, such as a body of law
coffre: a long flexible snout as of an elephant
cogner: pass out from weakness, physical or emotional distress due to a loss of blood supply to the brain
colibri: tiny American bird having brilliant iridescent plumage and long slender bills; wings are specialized for vibrating flight

combat: an energetic attempt to achieve something
commande: the act of getting possession of something
compact: closely and firmly united or packed together
conduire: cause to undertake a certain action
copain: a member of the Religious Society of Friends founded by George Fox (the Friends have never called themselves Quakers)
corail: of a strong pink to yellowish-pink color
corpus: the main part of an organ or other bodily structure
correct: appropriate for a condition or purpose or occasion or a person's character, needs
cosmique: inconceivably extended in space or time
coude: shove one's elbow into another person's ribs
courage: a quality of spirit that enables you to face danger or pain without showing fear
couvrir: clothe, as if for protection from the elements
coyote: small wolf native to western North America
crabe: a stroke of the oar that either misses the water or digs too deeply
crainte: regard with feelings of respect and reverence; consider hallowed or exalted or be in awe of
cravate: a wrestling hold in which the opponent's head is locked between the crook of your elbow and the side of your body
crayon: write, draw, or trace with a pencil
creuser: the act of touching someone suddenly with your finger or elbow
crier: use foul or abusive language towards
cristal: a protective cover that protects the face of a watch
croire: bring into a given condition by mental preoccupation
crotale: pit viper with horny segments at the end of the tail that rattle when shaken
cuisine: the act of preparing something (as food) by the application of heat
cuivre: coat with a layer of copper
culminer: end, especially to reach a final or climactic stage
cupide: wanting to eat or drink more than one can reasonably consume
curatif: tending to cure or restore to health
curseur: (computer science) indicator consisting of a movable spot of light (an icon) on a visual display; moving it allows the user to point to commands or screen positions
cyanure: an extremely poisonous salt of hydrocyanic acid
cylindre: a hollow cast-iron cylinder attached to the wheel that forms part of the brakes
cynique: believing the worst of human nature and motives; having a sneering disbelief in e.g. selflessness of others
daigner: do something that one considers to be below one's dignity
damier: a board having 64 squares of two alternating colors
danger: a venture undertaken without regard to possible loss or injury

dialogue: a literary composition in the form of a conversation between two people
diamant: the area of a baseball field that is enclosed by 3 bases and home plate
dicter: say out loud for the purpose of recording

digne: having or expressing dignity; especially formality or stateliness in bearing or appearance

dimanche: first day of the week; observed as a day of rest and worship by most Christians
diminuer: decrease in size, extent, or range
dioxyde: an oxide containing two atoms of oxygen in the molecule
diriger: have a firm understanding or knowledge of; be on top of
discuter: discuss the pros and cons of an issue
divertir: appropriate (as property entrusted to one's care) fraudulently to one's own use
diviser: become separated into pieces or fragments
dogme: a doctrine or code of beliefs accepted as authoritative
doigt: indicate the fingering for the playing of musical scores for keyboard instruments
domaine: a partitioned section, chamber, or separate room within a larger enclosed area
domicile: housing that someone is living in
donateur: a writer whose work is published in a newspaper or magazine or as part of a book
donjon: the main tower within the walls of a medieval castle or fortress

dortoir: a room used primarily for sleeping
dorure: a coating of gold or of something that looks like gold
dosage: the quantity of an active agent (substance or radiation) taken in or absorbed at any one time
dotation: a deliberate act of acquisition of something, often without the permission of the owner
douter: consider unlikely or have doubts about
doyen: an administrator in charge of a division of a university or college
dragon: any of several small tropical Asian lizards capable of gliding by spreading winglike membranes on each side of the body
dresser: undergo training or instruction in preparation for a particular role, function, or profession
droiture: righteousness as a consequence of being honorable and honest
durcir: make more temperate, acceptable, or suitable by adding something else; moderate

effectif: presently existing in fact and not merely potential or possible
effigie: a representation of a person (especially in the form of sculpture)
effusion: the shedding of blood resulting in murder
embryon: an animal organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation that in higher forms merge into fetal stages but in lower forms terminate in commencement of larval life
employer: exerting shrewd or devious influence especially for one's own advantage
emporter: remove from a certain place, environment, or mental or emotional state; transport into a new location or state
emprise: worker who moves the camera around while a film or television show is being made
enclave: an enclosed territory that is culturally distinct from the foreign territory that surrounds it
endosser: serve as a means for expressing something
endroit: take a place in a competition; often followed by an ordinal
enduire: administer an oil or ointment to ; often in a religious ceremony of blessing
enfance: a member of a clan or tribe
enfermer: confine in or as if in a coop
engager: force or impel in an indicated direction
engin: equipment designed to serve a specific function
enjamber: the act of sitting or standing astride
enjeu: instrument of execution consisting of a vertical post that a victim is tied to for burning
enlever: remove something concrete, as by lifting, pushing, or taking off, or remove something abstract
enrichir: make better or improve in quality
enseigne: structure displaying a board on which advertisements can be posted
entier: to the greatest degree or extent; completely or entirely; (`full' in this sense is used as a combining form)
entourer: surround with a wall in order to fortify
entraver: located at or near the back of an animal
envahir: march aggressively into another's territory by military force for the purposes of conquest and occupation
envoyer: be made known; be disclosed or revealed
enzyme: (chemistry) a substance that initiates or accelerates a chemical reaction without itself being affected
erreur: a wrong action attributable to bad judgment or ignorance or inattention
escalier: a stairway (set of steps) between one floor or landing and the next
espadon: large toothless marine food fish with a long swordlike upper jaw; not completely cold-blooded i.e. they are able to warm their brains and eyes: worldwide in warm waters but feed on cold ocean floor coming to surface at night
espoir: intend with some possibility of fulfilment
esquiver: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of
essayer: put on a garment in order to see whether it fits and looks nice
essence: a volatile flammable mixture of hydrocarbons (hexane and heptane and octane etc.) derived from petroleum; used mainly as a fuel in internal-combustion engines
essieu: a shaft on which a wheel rotates
essorer: remove the moisture from and make dry
estime: an attitude of admiration or esteem
estrade: a platform raised above the surrounding level to give prominence to the person on it
ethnie: people of the same race or nationality who share a distinctive culture
euphorie: a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation
exact: conforming exactly or almost exactly to fact or to a standard or performing with total accuracy
exaucer: fill or meet a want or need
exclusif: not divided among or brought to bear on more than one object or objective
exemple: a task performed or problem solved in order to develop skill or understanding
exhorter: force or impel in an indicated direction
exigence: something that is required in advance
exposer: abandon by leaving out in the open air
exprimer: provide evidence for; stand as proof of; show by one's behavior, attitude, or external attributes
extraire: extract by the process of distillation
fable: a story about mythical or supernatural beings or events
facette: a distinct feature or element in a problem
facile: obtained with little effort or sacrifice, often obtained illegally
falaise: a steep high face of rock
famille: primary social group; parents and children
farceur: a person who enjoys telling or playing jokes
farouche: marked by extreme and violent energy
fatal: (usually followed by `to') determined by tragic fate
fatigue: labor of a nonmilitary kind done by soldiers (cleaning or digging or draining or so on)
faucon: clear mucus or food from one's throat
favori: preferred above all others and treated with partiality
fendoir: a butcher's knife having a large square blade
fermer: marked by fidelity to an original
ferveur: feelings of great warmth and intensity
festival: an organized series of acts and performances (usually in one place)
feutre: change texture so as to become matted and felt-like
figure: a predetermined set of movements in dancing or skating
filetage: the raised helical rib going around a screw
filleul: an infant who is sponsored by an adult (the godparent) at baptism
filmer: make a film or photograph of something
filou: a criminal who takes property belonging to someone else with the intention of keeping it or selling it
filtrer: remove by passing through a filter
financer: be a regular customer or client of
fiole: bottle that has a narrow neck
firme: the members of a business organization that owns or operates one or more establishments
flairer: the act of perceiving the odor of something
flamme: criticize harshly, usually via an electronic medium
fleur: develop or come to a promising stage
flore: (botany) a living organism lacking the power of locomotion
fluctuer: cause to fluctuate or move in a wavelike pattern
fluvial: of or relating to or happening in a river
fonderie: factory where metal castings are produced
fongible: of goods or commodities; freely exchangeable for or replaceable by another of like nature or kind in the satisfaction of an obligation
fontaine: a plumbing fixture that provides a flow of water
forgeron: a smith who forges and shapes iron with a hammer and anvil
formuler: elaborate, as of theories and hypotheses
fortune: the property of being extremely abundant
fossile: set in a rigidly conventional pattern of behavior, habits, or beliefs
foudre: the flash of light that accompanies an electric discharge in the atmosphere (or something resembling such a flash); can scintillate for a second or more
fourmi: social insect living in organized colonies; characteristically the males and fertile queen have wings during breeding season; wingless sterile females are the workers
fragile: exquisitely fine and subtle and pleasing; susceptible to injury
fraise: machine tool in which metal that is secured to a carriage is fed against rotating cutters that shape it
franchir: trace a line through or across
friction: effort expended in moving one object over another with pressure
frontal: of or adjacent to the forehead or frontal bone
frotter: the act of rubbing or wiping
fruit: an animal organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation that in higher forms merge into fetal stages but in lower forms terminate in commencement of larval life
fugitif: lasting for a markedly brief time
fuite: tube inserted into a body cavity (as during surgery) to remove unwanted material
furieux: excessively agitated; distraught with fear or other violent emotion
fusion: the act of fusing (or melting) together
futur: coming at a subsequent time or stage
gagner: be the winner in a contest or competition; be victorious
galaxie: a splendid assemblage (especially of famous people)
galerie: an enclosed passageway; rooms usually open onto it
garantir: assure somebody of the truth of something with the intention of giving the listener confidence
gardien: a person who cares for persons or property
garnir: make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.
gazelle: small swift graceful antelope of Africa and Asia having lustrous eyes
gazon: a field of cultivated and mowed grass
gendarme: a lawman with less authority and jurisdiction than a sheriff
genou: joint between the femur and tibia in a quadruped; corresponds to the human knee
gentil: charming in a childlike or naive way
germe: a minute life form (especially a disease-causing bacterium); the term is not in technical use
gibier: your occupation or line of work
gicler: move or act with a sudden increase in speed or energy
glisser: the act of moving smoothly along a surface while remaining in contact with it
globe: a sphere on which a map (especially of the earth) is represented
gloire: French couturier (born in England) regarded as the founder of Parisian haute couture; noted for introducing the bustle (1825-1895)
golfeur: someone who plays the game of golf
gorge: a passage resembling a throat in shape or function
gorille: largest anthropoid ape; terrestrial and vegetarian; of forests of central west Africa
gouffre: holding device consisting of one or both of the opposing parts of a tool that close to hold an object
goupille: a cotter consisting of a split pin that is secured (after passing through a hole) by splitting the ends apart
gourmand: given to excess in consumption of especially food or drink
goutte: a curtain that can be lowered and raised onto a stage from the flies; often used as background scenery
graffiti: a rude decoration inscribed on rocks or walls
grappin: a tool consisting of several hooks for grasping and holding; often thrown with a rope
grenat: any of a group of hard glassy minerals (silicates of various metals) used as gemstones and as an abrasive
griller: size or measure according to a scale
grimper: increase in value or to a higher point
grogner: to utter or emit low dull rumbling sounds
groupe: any number of entities (members) considered as a unit
guerrier: having or showing a ready disposition to fight
guide: something that offers basic information or instruction
guimauve: spongy confection made of gelatin and sugar and corn syrup and dusted with powdered sugar

terminer: bring to an end or halt
terrible: causing fear or dread or terror
thorax: part of an insect's body that bears the wings and legs
tibia: climb awkwardly, as if by scrambling
timide: showing fear and lack of confidence
tirelire: a child's coin bank (often shaped like a pig)
tiroir: a boxlike container in a piece of furniture; made so as to slide in and out
tissu: artifact made by weaving or felting or knitting or crocheting natural or synthetic fibers
titane: a light strong grey lustrous corrosion-resistant metallic element used in strong lightweight alloys (as for airplane parts); the main sources are rutile and ilmenite
tituber: walk as if unable to control one's movements
toboggan: plaything consisting of a sloping chute down which children can slide
tomate: mildly acid red or yellow pulpy fruit eaten as a vegetable
tonneau: the act of changing the institution that invests your pension plan without incurring a tax penalty
toponyme: the name by which a geographical place is known
tordre: twist suddenly so as to sprain
tornade: a purified and potent form of cocaine that is smoked rather than snorted; highly addictive
torrent: a violently fast stream of water (or other liquid)
torse: a broken piece of a brittle artifact
tortue: hunt for turtles, especially as an occupation
totem: a tribal emblem consisting of a pillar carved and painted with totemic figures; erected by Indian tribes of the northwest Pacific coast
toucher: the act of putting two things together with no space between them
tousser: exhale abruptly, as when one has a chest cold or congestion
toxine: a poisonous substance produced during the metabolism and growth of certain microorganisms and some higher plant and animal species
traction: the act of dragging (pulling with force)
trafic: social or verbal interchange (usually followed by `with')
tragique: very sad; especially involving grief or death or destruction
trahir: cause someone to believe an untruth
train: exercise in order to prepare for an event or competition
travail: activity directed toward making or doing something
tremper: cover with liquid; pour liquid onto
tribunal: the act of judging or assessing a person or situation or event
tricoter: to gather something into small wrinkles or folds
trilogie: a set of three literary or dramatic works related in subject or theme
trombone: a wire or plastic clip for holding sheets of paper together
tronc: the body excluding the head and neck and limbs
tropical: of weather or climate; hot and humid as in the tropics
tumulte: a state of extreme confusion and disorder
turbine: rotary engine in which the kinetic energy of a moving fluid is converted into mechanical energy by causing a bladed rotor to rotate
tuteur: providing protective supervision; watching over or safeguarding
tutoyer: the cardinal number that is the product of 10 and 100
tympan: the membrane in the ear that vibrates to sound
typhon: (Greek mythology) a monster with a hundred heads who breathed out flames; son of Typhoeus and father of Cerberus and the Chimera and the Sphinx
typique: of a feature that helps to distinguish a person or thing; - Curtis Wilkie
ultime: not to be altered or undone
ultrason: using the reflections of high-frequency sound waves to construct an image of a body organ (a sonogram); commonly used to observe fetal growth or study bodily organs
union: the act of making or becoming a single unit
unique: highly unusual or rare but not the single instance
unitaire: a class of one kind of unit in a system of numbers or measures or weights or money
univers: everything stated or assumed in a given discussion
uranium: a heavy toxic silvery-white radioactive metallic element; occurs in many isotopes; used for nuclear fuels and nuclear weapons
urbain: located in or characteristic of a city or city life
usage: exerting shrewd or devious influence especially for one's own advantage
usuel: occurring or encountered or experienced or observed frequently or in accordance with regular practice or procedure
usure: the act of lending money at an exorbitant rate of interest
utopie: a state of mind characterized by abstraction and release from reality
vacarme: the auditory experience of sound that lacks musical quality; sound that is a disagreeable auditory experience
vaccin: immunogen consisting of a suspension of weakened or dead pathogenic cells injected in order to stimulate the production of antibodies
vagabond: continually changing especially as from one abode or occupation to another
vague: weak in willpower, courage or vitality
vaillant: disposed to venture or take risks
vaincre: to put down by force or authority
valise: a portable rectangular container for carrying clothes
valve: control consisting of a mechanical device for controlling the flow of a fluid
vampire: any of various tropical American bats of the family Desmodontidae that bite mammals and birds to feed on their blood
vanille: a distinctive fragrant flavor characteristic of vanilla beans
vapeur: cook something by letting steam pass over it
varier: become different in some particular way, without permanently losing one's or its former characteristics or essence
vassal: a person holding a fief; a person who owes allegiance and service to a feudal lord
vaste: unusually great in size or amount or degree or especially extent or scope; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; - W.R.Inge
vecteur: a variable quantity that can be resolved into components
vendredi: the sixth day of the week; the fifth working day
venger: take revenge for a perceived wrong
venimeux: marked by deep ill will; deliberately harmful
verrou: the part of a lock that is engaged or withdrawn with a key
verser: bear (a cost or penalty), in recompense for some action
viaduc: bridge consisting of a series of arches supported by piers used to carry a road (or railroad) over a valley
victoire: the outcome of a game or contest
vilain: a wicked or evil person; someone who does evil deliberately
village: a community of people smaller than a town
vinaigre: sour-tasting liquid produced usually by oxidation of the alcohol in wine or cider and used as a condiment or food preservative
virement: the act of transfering something from one form to another
virtuose: having or revealing supreme mastery or skill
virus: (virology) ultramicroscopic infectious agent that replicates itself only within cells of living hosts; many are pathogenic; a piece of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) wrapped in a thin coat of protein
visqueux: having the sticky properties of an adhesive
vitrine: a piece of furniture resembling a cupboard with doors and shelves and drawers; for storage or display
vocation: the particular occupation for which you are trained
voile: an ocean trip taken for pleasure
voisin: be located near or adjacent to
volaille: a domesticated gallinaceous bird thought to be descended from the red jungle fowl
volcan: a fissure in the earth's crust (or in the surface of some other planet) through which molten lava and gases erupt
voltiger: move along rapidly and lightly; skim or dart
volume: how much there is or how many there are of something that you can quantify
vorace: given to excess in consumption of especially food or drink
vortex: a powerful circular current of water (usually the result of conflicting tides)
voter: a choice that is made by counting the number of people in favor of each alternative
voyage: the act of going from one place to another
voyelle: a speech sound made with the vocal tract open
wagon: a wheeled vehicle adapted to the rails of railroad
zoologie: the branch of biology that studies animals
